text: OREN LIEBERMANN: Just days into

Israeli Prime Minister
Benjamin Netanyahu

announced a major
surge in construction
in West Bank settlements.

Netanyahu said he
and the defense

minister have approved 2,500 new
housing units in the West Bank.

In a tweet, he said,
"We are building
and we will continue to build."

It wasn't long ago, not
even a few weeks ago,

that Netanyahu said,
"A new era is coming,

and it's coming soon,"
a clear reference
to Trump's presidency.

For Netanyahu, this
now is that new era,

and he's acting as if he
has the cover of the Trump

administration after
President Barack

Obama routinely condemned
settlement construction.

Netanyahu has been
under pressure

here from his right
wing government
to advance settlement growth.

Some politicians have even
called on Netanyahu to annex
parts of the West Bank.

He rebuffed those calls,
instead announcing
this new construction.

The defense minister
said most of the units

are in the settlement blocks,
but about 100 units are
in the settlement of Beit El.

That's noteworthy because Trump
donated to that settlement
back in 2003.

Palestinians condemned
this settlement growth.

Hanan Ashrawi, a member of
the PLO executive committee,

said, "It is evident that Israel
is exploiting the inauguration

of the new American
administration

to escalate its violations and
the prevention of any existence
of a Palestinian state."

Israel hasn't advanced
plans this large,

this many housing units in
the West Bank, in years.

And these plans
come just one day

after the White House
seemed to back off

of one of Trump's major
campaign promises,

to move the embassy from
Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.

The White House press
secretary said a decision
hasn't been made on that yet.
Oren Liebermann, Jerusalem.
